instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.ISL6258: What is ISL6258? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2008 through 2009.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message:
[SIZE=14px]Hi, I have same 2 Boards and no green or orange light, no Fan spin, no Power up to start.[/SIZE]  [FONT=Courier][SIZE=18px][SIZE=14px][I]3.425V "G3Hot" Supply exists.
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>= 3,2V
<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_CONN</SIGNAL> = 18,77V
<SIGNAL>ONEWIRE_EN</SIGNAL> = 9,27V[/I]

I'm am despair, please help![/SIZE][/SIZE][/FONT]

PIN 4 of <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> <SIGNAL>ONEWIRE_OVERVOLT</SIGNAL> give 0,02V, is this normal?

threads.message: 12.3V output means the SMC is not running it should be 12.6. Check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and check for corrosion around SMC.

come on Guys please help me!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message: There is nothing to the <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> circuit. If it gets 3V42 on pin 2 and pin 5 over 2.5V it will enable pin 1. Checked <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message: Yes, pin 1 is 3,416V and pin 2 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message: I also asked pin 5 and <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR>. Resistance to GND on pin 2 is also important. You need to show some initiative here too!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message: Pin 5 to GND of <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> is 3,148V and pin 2 of <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> to GND is 3,416V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message: I mean pin 1 and pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> to GND!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message:
He asked for resistance to ground. This means that you need to stop applying power to the board and turn the multimeter to ohms mode rather than volts. 

This playlist might help you if this is confusing. [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0nS-HQ1PKMQ&list=PLkVbIsAWN2ltOWmriIdOc5CtiZqUTH7GT&index=5[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message:
Let's cover two things.

[B]Firstly[/B], 0.8v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> usually means <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing. Without <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> going to the ISL, it will not produce more than 0.7v-0.8v. You have been measuring, probing around, and replacing chips powered by <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>. Is <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> still present? If it goes away, 0.7v-0.8v is what you get on <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL>. 

[B]Secondly[/B], I think this is a good time to set a precedent here: this is the second time you've mentioned that. This isn't something I felt like making into a sticky or getting into too far, but it's something that will have to be discussed sooner or later, and this is a better time than any.

In the first page of the thread, duke helped you and you ignored his help, ignored his question, did something differently than what he asked, and complained that no one was helping you. Now, you have received a lot of help, but seem irritated that we did not reply again immediately.

I can't speak for Duke, but I personally appreciate every single person who decided to give up their hard earned $29/month for the ability to receive advice from us. [B]Thank you very much, from the bottom of my heart, all of you, for doing that[/B]. Seriously, not trolling here; it is appreciated, and we will work our asses off to live up to that.

[B]THAT BEING SAID [/B]:)

I am more than happy to refund your money [I]early[/I] into your subscription if you feel this is not helpful. I do not want to foster an environment of people ignoring advice, doing the opposite of what we say, and then getting mad when it doesn't work out. Further, I do not want to set the precedent of there being an expectation that every single question will have [I]instant [/I]answers. Above all, I cannot set a precedent that every board is fixable. Many are fixable, but many are trash. I log into this place at least seven times a day, often from the gym, work, train, before I go to sleep... I can't be at a point where when I log in, I have to worry that people are angry that I haven't logged in enough. $29/month buys answers, but if I have to tell duke that he has to stop his BGA machine in the middle of a $500 repair to post here, I'm going to have to pay him considerably more money. He is a limited resource you will not find [I]anywhere else[/I][I]. [/I]The same goes for myself with this: If I have to jump out of a security system installation because someone is going to get mad that a brunch question was answered at lunchtime, then the rate is not going to be $29. More like $500.

Duke and I are where we are because we spend 25 hours a day in front of these problems beating our head against the wall to figure them out, on systems that were never meant to be documented or troubleshooted by technicians. This is what makes us good at our job; please understand this. Please don't abuse this resource by throwing a fit if you do not receive an instant reply. 

If you feel the need to do so, or if these terms do not make sense, I have no problem refunding you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no green or orange light / does not start
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Berky, post: 853"]I have resolder <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and now comes 12,27V on F7040. Have anyone idea?[/QUOTE]
When <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is down by 2% it means the SMC is not on.
